The Clusters Property Page allows you to add, edit and remove clusters to and from your projects the configuration(s).To learn more about what a cluster is an how they are an essential part of the Eiffel environment please refer to the
/general\guided_tour\language\tutorial-04.xml guided tour .
Recommended: It is recommended that you add, edit or removeclusters to the current project with 'All Configurations' selected in the Configuration option at the top of the Property Page Dialog, unless you need different clusters for each one of the configurations. Doing this will save you time as you will only have to add a cluster once instead ofonce for every configuration.
Clusters Property Page clusters_ppg.png
2Cluster Hierarchy
The Cluster Hierarchy shows all of the explicitly added clusters to the current selected project configuration. To add or remove clusters from the hierarchy, use the Add and Remove buttons located to the right on the it.
Adding a Cluster
Clusters are based on a hierarchical system where a single cluster may have zero or more child clusters and those clusters, if any, it turn may also have child clusters of their own. This means there are two ways to add a cluster. Add a cluster with a parent or without. To add a cluster to the root of the project (without a parent) simply click the root tree view node (this will displayed asthe System Name set in the General page) and then click the Add button. To add a child cluster simply highlight the corresponding parent cluster node in the tree view, then click the Add button.
You should now be presented with the option to edit the cluster name (by default the cluster name will be new_cluster( nth) where ( nth) is the index if new_cluster already existing in any one of the projects configurations). You must enter a valid cluster name governed by the following rules
Should begin with a character between 'a' to 'z' or 'A' to 'Z'.
Shouldonly contain alphanumerical characters and underscores thereafter (no white spaces).
Must not already be in use by any other cluster in any one of the selected configurations.
Removing A Cluster
Note: Removing a cluster from the project is irreversible unless you click 'Cancel' on the Property Page Dialog.
To remove a clustersimplyselect the cluster to be removed from the project configuration and then click the Remove button, right of the Cluster Hierarchy. Once clicked you will need to confirm the removal of the selected cluster. Clicking OK on the confirmation dialog removes the cluster, Cancel leaves the cluster in the current configuration.
Note: If the selected cluster has one or more children clusters, if you choose to remove the cluster all child clusters will also be removed from the current configuration.
Renaming a Cluster
It is also possible to rename cluster. Slowly double click on the cluster node you would to change and you will be presented withan edit box for you to enter the new name. Use the tab key or click else where in the property page to continue.
2Basic Cluster Properties
Cluster Path
The Cluster Path property is the location of the cluster where the compiler will look for Eiffel class .e files. Every cluster must have a path. For clusters that are achild of another cluster, you may use a relative path prefixed with a dollar symbol ($), which represents the pathof the parent clusters. You must follow the $ with a backslash (\) as the directory seperator or the the two paths will be concatinated and may cause a compilation error or even have the cluster point to a undesired location.
Include Subdirectories
Checking this option will inform the compiler to recursively traverse through all the subdirectories located at the specified cluster path.
Namespace
Be default the compiler will use the cluster name as the part of the overall namespace in the assembly manifest. Specifying a namespace will override this behaviour and make use of the specified namespace instead of the cluster name.
Note: A namespaces must begin with an alpha character and succeeded by and alphanumberical, underscore (_) or period (.). The character following a period must also only be an alpha character.
2General Properties
Override
The override option can only be applied to one cluster in each configuration. This property is to resolve any class name clashes between the selected cluster and anycluster in the configuration without the need to
#cluster_excludes exclude individual files. The cluster that has the Override property checked will be cluster who's classes are used over any of the other clusters in the universe.
Library
The Library property is similar to Include Subdirectories in that it traverses through a clusters subdirectories. A library cluster, however, is a cluster who's contents in compiled once per configuration. Any modification to any class from a library cluster will not have any affect unless a Rebuild or a Clean and then Build is performed on the project.
2Cluster Excludes
Ifeither the
#include_subdirectories Include Subcdirectories or
#LibraryAndAll Library property for the selected cluster have been checked then the compile will recursively look in all of the clusterssub-directories for classes. This maylead to class name conficts as different libraries may use the same name for classes.In this situationyou can choose to exclude any subdirectoryfrom being searched or any file being include by the compiler at compile time.
The current cluster excluded items list is located underneath the
#namespace Namespace property, accompanied by an Add and a Remove button.
Adding an Item to Exclude
To add a newitem to the list of excluded item, click Add next to the Excludes list. An edit box will appear at the end of the Excludes list allowing you to enter the name of a file or directory to exclude.
Remove ExcludedItems
To remove one or more items, select the items you would like to have removed from the list and click Remove button next the the Excludes list.
Renaming an Excluded Item
To rename an already excluded item, slowly double click on the item you would to change. And edit box will then appear for you to enter the new name.
2Cluster Level Assertions
Use Defaults
When Use Defaults is checked the assertion specified in the Assertions Property Page are used for the cluster. If you want more fine grained control over assertions on a per cluster level then uncheck this property. Unchecking Use Default will enable the assertion check boxes below.
Require
Checking this property will perform runtime precondition assertion verification on all class located in the currently selected cluster.
Ensure
Checking this property will perform runtime postcondition assertion verification on all class located in the currently selected cluster.
Check
Checking this property will perform runtime check assertion verification on all class located in the currently selected cluster.
Loop
Checking this property will perform runtime loop variant assertion verification on all class located in the currently selected cluster.
Invariant
Checking this property will perform runtime invariant assertion verification on all class located in the currently selected cluster.Setting
2Using the Cluster Property Page with Multiple Configurations
When viewing the cluster property page using more that one configuration, thecluster hierarchywill only show the clusters common to all configurations. The common factor is simply the cluster's name and it's position in the cluster hierarchy. For the individual cluster properties where an uncommon value between all configuration is found the property remains blank,check boxes will show and intermediate selected state andthe cluster Exludes list will only show those common excluded items in the list. You are free to modify and change any property, regardless of its state. Once changed, the change will be reflected in all of the selected configurations.
Adding A Cluster With Multiple Configurations
When adding a cluster to multiple configurations it is not possible to give the new cluster the same name as any other cluster in any of the included configurations.
